title: Pre-course survey
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Below is a link to a Pre-course survey. This survey is entirely optional, but can be filled out, even if you start the course late or leave early.

Your feedback is invaluable to us in improving the course and learning experience for future participants. If you choose to complete the survey, please complete the Consent Form which precedes the survey. Some data gathered may be used for research purposes.

In addition, if you are yet to complete the More About You survey from FutureLearn or need to update your details, you can complete it HERE.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the survey, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

Please note: We are aware that there are some browser issues that some may experience. If you are on a mobile device you should be able to zoom and pan with the pinch gesture. If you are on a desktop and the scrollbar is not visible reduce the width of your window or click and drag when your cursor turns into a crosshair. This survey does not work on Android devices. If you would like to submit a response to the survey please use a non-Android device.

]

title: Introductions and motivation
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Why did you enrol in this course? What do you hope to learn?

In this course, we will be discussing a lot of current issues in the field of personalised medicine, so let’s get to know each other a little better and discuss why we are all here.

In this activity, we’d like you to introduce yourself to the other learners and to tell us why you enrolled!

  • Where are you from?
  • What do you do?
  • Why are you interested in personalised medicine and what would you like to learn in this course?
    • </ul>
    You can Like and reply to comments posted by others and follow other like-minded learners you find along the way. This will make it easier for you to see their comments on future steps by filtering the discussion.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Basic medical genetics
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[
View transcript
Download video: standard or HD
]

title: Are you similar or different to your family?
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Physical traits are a simple way to begin to think about how genes are inherited from one generation to another.

How much of what we are is determined by our genes and how much by nature? In this discussion, let’s begin thinking about the influence of nature versus nurture.

In this activity, consider the following questions:

  • Do you look similar to your parents and siblings?
  • Are you taller or shorter, do you have the same eye colour perhaps?
  • How are you different?
  • Are you aware of diseases that "run in families"?
  • Do these genetic traits or diseases appear consistently in your family tree or are they random?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Environment, genetics or both?
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Before we delve into too much content, we are interested to learn what you think about the contribution of our genes (nature) or our environment (nurture) to personal traits and diseases.

In the following activity you can select to what extent genes or the environment contribute to the personal traits and diseases listed.

Upon completion of the activity, you will be shown the average of genetic or environmental contribution to each trait or disease as voted by your peers. Take a moment to look at the results and consider how they differ with your choices. Poll results will update in real time so remember to check back regularly to see how the results change over time! You can access the results HERE.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Nature or nurture? Your thoughts
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Were you surprised by the group results?

As you can see from the previous activity, our perceptions of the role genetics and the environment play on development of personal traits and disease is hard to quantify.

Before moving on, consider the following:

  • Were your answers very different from those of the whole cohort?
  • Why do you think this was?

In the discussion let us know which diseases or traits surprised you.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Commercial genetic testing - would you do it?
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

Now that you know a little about sequencing and genetic testing, do you think this is something you would do voluntarily?

In this exercise, consider whether you would undertake commercial genetic testing. Once again, you’ll be able to see the results of the entire cohort, so if you’re one of the first to take the poll, check back later to see how the results have changed. You can access the results HERE.

Do the results surprise you? Tell us your thoughts in the comments section for this step.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Scenario: If you had the means
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

In this hypothetical scenario you are asked to consider what choices you would make if you had the money and time to research and design a personalised healthcare treatment for a loved one.

The scenario below will give you an insight into one family’s extraordinary efforts to help a loved one with a terminal illness. There are no right or wrong answers for this activity. This exercise is designed to show the complexities of personalised healthcare.

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. You can access the results HERE. You will also be given access to the original media article that the scenario is based upon to see what actually happened.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Scenario reflection
week_heading: Week 1: Causes of Disease and the Genetic Revolution
step_content:
[

You’ve just completed the ethical scenario for this week. What did you decide to do?

Tell us your thoughts in the discussion. You might like to consider the following questions when thinking about your post:

  • Did you find the ethical questions difficult to answer?
  • Having completed the scenario, what, if anything, would you do differently?
  • What did you learn from completing the activity?

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Genetic testing for a high risk cancer gene
step_content:
[

Now that you know more about the genetic counselling process, how would you feel about having your genome sequenced?

What if it identified a high risk genetic mutation?

In the following activity you can select whether you would have genetic testing.

Upon completion of the activity, you will be shown the results of the poll as voted by your peers. Take a moment to look at the results and consider how they differ from your original choice. Poll results will update in real time so remember to check back regularly to see how the results change over time! You can access the results HERE. Let us know your thoughts in the comments section for this step.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Scenario: Genetic testing for breast cancer
step_content:
[

Some breast cancers are caused by a hereditary BRCA1/BRCA2 gene mutation. In this hypothetical scenario your partner’s mother died of breast cancer. You now have children, two of which are female. You heard about genetic testing to determine an individual’s risk of developing cancer. What would you do?

Like the scenario last week, there are no right or wrong answers for this activity. This exercise is designed to show the complexities of personalised healthcare.

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. You can access the results HERE. You will also be given access to the original media article that the scenario is based upon to see what actually happened.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Scenario: Using HIV to cure cancer
step_content:
[

In this hypothetical scenario, you have the opportunity to test a revolutionary new therapy using a modified version of the HIV virus to help destroy Leukaemic cells in a child.

For this exercise, consider your choice from both the perspective of a doctor or a parent. How far would you go to help a sick child?

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. You can access the results HERE. You will also be given access to the original media article that the scenario is based upon to see what actually happened.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

title: Scenario: Genetic testing and neurological disease
step_content:
[

Imagine you knew exactly how your life would progress, how and when you would die and that this information could be available by way of a simple genetic test. How would you live your life?

In this hypothetical scenario, you will consider how knowing the results of the genetic test may impact on your whole life.

Like the scenario last week, there are no right or wrong answers for this activity. This exercise is designed to show the complexities of personalised healthcare.

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. title: Personalised Medicine Today
step_content:
[

This week we’ve learnt quite a bit about personalised medicine and its effect on medical treatment across the fields of cancer, neurological diseases and infectious diseases.

In this activity, consider the following:

  • What impact is personalised medicine having TODAY in your country?
    • You might wish to choose a specific disease (for example breast cancer, Alzheimer's disease or HIV) and reflect on how advances in genetics and genomics have changed the diagnosis and treatment of specific diseases.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Scenario: Childhood vaccination
step_content:
[

In many countries there is a recommended immunisation schedule for children. However, some immunisations, such as the flu, are egg based.

In this hypothetical scenario you are asked to consider what you would do if your child has an egg allergy. Would you choose to vaccinate them or not?

Like the scenario last week, there are no right or wrong answers for this activity. This exercise is designed to show the complexities of personalised healthcare.

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. You can access the results HERE You will also be given access to the original media article that the scenario is based upon to see what actually happened.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Medicines development pathway
step_content:
[

Before we move on to learning about how medicines are developed, let’s see what you already know.

This activity will give you a chance to see how much you already know about the steps involved in getting a medicine to market. Simply type a number from 1 to 7 in the field next to the name of the medicines development step. Although there is a correct answer for this activity, it doesn’t matter if you get it wrong. We’ll have a chance to revisit the activity, where we will show you the answer after the next video.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

title: Scenario: Twitterstorm
step_content:
[

In this hypothetical scenario, you are the head of a small biotech company with two promising antiviral drugs. One drug successfully treated infections in 90% of patients. The second drug was successful in only 60% of patients, however, it was found to be very effective in treating a mutated strain of virus that only affects 5% of the population.

For this exercise, consider which drug you would choose to develop further.

As with previous exercises, you will be able to see what choices your peers made for this activity once you have completed it. You can check back any time to see how the results change. You can access the results HERE. You will also be given access to the original media article that the scenario is based upon to see what actually happened.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Commercial genetic testing - would you do it?
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

In Week 1 we asked whether you would undertake commercial genetic testing, now we will revisit the activity to see if, as a group, your attitudes have changed.

As before, consider whether you would undertake commercial genetic testing. You’ll be able to see the results of the entire cohort, so if you’re one of the first to take the poll, check back later to see how the results have changed. You can access the results HERE.

Take a moment to look at the results and compare them with the original results from Step 1.14.

Once you’ve completed the exercise, consider the following:

  • Do the results surprise you?
  • What differences did you notice between the first and second attempts?
  • Have you changed your mind since Week 1?
    • Tell us your thoughts in the comments section for this step.

    If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au.

    Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.
]

title: Genetic testing and lifestyle changes
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

If you had genetic testing, how would knowing the results influence your lifestyle?

In this activity, we will consider whether knowing the results of a genetic test would cause you to change aspects of your lifestyle. You’ll be able to see the results of the entire cohort, so if you’re one of the first to take the poll, check back later to see how the results have changed. You can view the results HERE.

Do the results surprise you? Tell us your thoughts in the comments section for this step.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au.

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

]

title: Revisited - environment, genetics or both?
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

We’ve almost reached the end of the course, and we’ve learnt a lot along the way. How have your perceptions of genetics and the environment changed when thinking about their contribution to personal traits and diseases?

In the following activity you can drag the slider more towards genes or environment to show how much you think each contributes to the personal trait or disease listed.

Upon completion of the activity, you will be shown the average percentage of genetic or environmental contribution to each trait or disease as voted by your peers.

Take a moment to look at the results HERE and compare them with the original results from Step 1.7.

Before moving on, consider the following:

  • What differences did you notice between the first and second attempts?
  • How have your own views changed?</li>

    Let us know your thoughts in the comments section for this step. We will elaborate on your results in the feedback video at the conclusion of this week.

    If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au. Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the exercise, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.
]

title: Have your views changed?
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

Throughout the last 5 weeks, we hope you’ve learnt a lot about the complex nature of the genetic revolution and the evolution of personalised medicine.

In this discussion, consider the following:

  • Have your views changed since you began the course?
  • How and why have your views changed since the the beginning of the course?</li>

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Weekly resources
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

We’ve now reached the end of Week 5.

Each week, you will find a list of additional resources for you to read in your own time, if you wish. We’ve divided the resources by relevant video for that week, and grouped each resource into either a media article, a website, a journal article or a video.

You can download a list of resources for this week in the Downloads section below. Each resource title is hyperlinked to the original article.

Are there any resources that you’ve found interesting or informative in your own studies? Let us know in the comments section for this step.

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

Below is a link to a Post-course survey. This survey is entirely optional, but can be filled out, even if you start the course late or leave early.

Your feedback is invaluable to us in improving the course and learning experience for future participants. If you choose to complete the survey, please complete the Consent Form which precedes the survey. Some data gathered may be used for research purposes.

In addition, if you are yet to complete the More About You survey from FutureLearn or need to update your details, you can complete it HERE.

If you experience any technical difficulties in accessing the activity, please send us a screen shot, description of your operating system (OS), web browser and steps taken to MOOCs@unsw.edu.au

Select the Launch button below to begin. Once you have completed the survey, select to go Back to course in the top left corner. You can then mark the step and complete and move on to the next step.

Please note: this survey does not work on Android devices. If you would like to submit a response to the survey please use a non-Android device.

title: You've made it!
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

Well done on reaching the end of the course! We’ve thoroughly enjoyed reading your insightful comments on the many varied and complex issues of personalised medicine and the genetic revolution.

We’ve thoroughly enjoyed creating this course and sharing it with so many people from so many different parts of the world. We hope you’ve enjoyed hearing from a range of experts each specialising in different aspects of personalised medicine. As academics we are used to teaching large classes of students from many different cultures, but this online course has allowed us to learn so much more about aspects of personalised medicine we couldn’t have hoped to achieve in a single face to face course, so thank you all for your wonderful contributions to the course.

To be eligible to buy a Statement of Participation, you must have completed more than 50% of the steps in a course (by using the “Mark as complete” button on each step). You can also purchase a Certificate of Achievement. You must mark over 90% of course steps as complete and attempt all test questions, achieving a score of over 70%. FutureLearn will email you once you become eligible. You can check how close you are to being eligible on your course progress page.

If you found this course interesting, let your friends and colleagues know about it. This course will run again in early 2017. You can register your interest HERE.

We wish you all the very best.

Caroline Ford, Orin Chishom, Sheri Nixdorf and Rachel Williams

© UNSW Australia 2016

]

title: Acknowledgements
week_heading: Week 5: The Impact of Personalised Medicine on Wider Society
step_content:
[

We would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have helped produce this MOOC.

Special thanks to our course mentors, Dr. Chaturaka Rodrigo and Ms. Claire Henry for their assistance during the course. We would also like to thank the Learning Design and Development Services team at UNSW Australia for their assistance with video editing, survey evaluation support and educational design. We wish to thank the Faculty of Medicine as well as Media and Marketing at UNSW Australia and the FutureLearn team for their help and support. We would also like to acknowledge The Creative Foundry for their continued assistance with video resourcing.

Our deepest thanks to all the guest presenters who gave of their time to provide the insightful content that makes up this course. Without their support, this MOOC would not have been possible.

Finally, we would like to thank you and the contributions you have made during this course. We have learnt so much from all of you and the perspectives you have brought to the field of personalised medicine have truely made this a global experience for all of us.

We will be offering this course again in 2017. If you found this course interesting, let your friends and colleagues know about it.

Best wishes,

Caroline Ford, Orin Chisholm, Sheri Nixdorf, Rachel Williams

© UNSW Australia 2016

]
